content: The "Small Business Incentive Act of 1993" amends the Securities Act of 1933 to increase the exemption threshold from $5,000,000 to $10,000,000 and excludes certain securities from the definition of an investment company. Section 3(c) of the Investment Company Act of 1940 is amended to deem certain issuers as investment companies for specific purposes related to limitations on securities transactions with registered investment companies. The Investment Company Act of 1940 is amended to classify certain issuers as investment companies for the purpose of restricting securities transactions with registered investment companies. The amendment includes provisions regarding the sale of securities issued by registered open-end investment companies to such issuers. The Investment Company Act of 1940 is amended to classify certain issuers as investment companies for the purpose of restricting securities transactions with registered investment companies. The amendment includes provisions regarding the sale of securities issued by registered open-end investment companies to such issuers. The amendment also modifies the criteria for issuers whose securities are owned exclusively by qualified purchasers. The Investment Company Act of 1940 is amended to classify certain issuers as investment companies for the purpose of restricting securities transactions with registered investment companies. This includes limitations on the purchase and sale of securities issued by registered open-end investment companies to such issuers. SEC. 4. DEFINITION OF QUALIFIED PURCHASER. The Investment Company Act of 1940 defines a "qualified purchaser" as a natural person with at least $10,000,000 in securities or an entity with at least $100,000,000 in securities for discretionary investment. The Investment Company Act of 1940 defines a "qualified purchaser" as a person who owns and invests at least $100,000,000 in securities of non-affiliated issuers on a discretionary basis, or as determined by the Commission for those needing less protection under the Act. The Commission may determine that certain individuals with a high level of financial sophistication, sizable net worth, substantial assets, or a relationship with an issuer do not need the protections of the Investment Company Act of 1940. The Commission may exempt individuals with significant financial sophistication, net worth, assets, or issuer relationships from certain provisions of the Investment Company Act of 1940. The Commission may also establish rules for these individuals as deemed necessary for public interest and investor protection. SEC. 5 of the Investment Company Act of 1940 is amended to redefine investment securities. SEC. 6 provides exemptions for economic, business, and industrial development companies. The Investment Company Act of 1940 is amended to include a new paragraph regarding companies not issuing redeemable securities but regulated by the state. The Investment Company Act of 1940 is amended to include a new paragraph allowing companies in a state to provide financial or managerial assistance to businesses operating in that state. The Investment Company Act of 1940 is amended to allow companies in a state to provide financial or managerial assistance to businesses operating in that state, as well as engage in activities necessary to carry out that purpose. Securities of the company must be primarily held by individuals residing or having a substantial business presence in that state after each sale. The Investment Company Act of 1940 is amended to allow companies in a state to provide financial or managerial assistance to businesses operating in that state. Sales of securities must be made by persons residing or having a substantial business presence in that state, and sold solely to accredited investors or other persons permitted by the Commission. The Investment Company Act of 1940 is amended to allow companies in a state to provide financial or managerial assistance to businesses operating in that state. Sales of securities must be made by persons residing or having a substantial business presence in that state, and sold solely to accredited investors or other persons permitted by the Commission. The company is prohibited from purchasing securities issued by investment companies, except for those rated investment grade by at least one nationally recognized agency. The Investment Company Act of 1940 is amended to allow companies in a state to provide financial or managerial assistance to businesses operating in that state. Sales of securities must be made by persons residing or having a substantial business presence in that state, and sold solely to accredited investors or other persons permitted by the Commission. The company is prohibited from purchasing securities issued by investment companies, except for those rated investment grade by at least one nationally recognized agency. Exclusions from the definition of investment company include securities rated investment grade or issued by registered open-end investment companies investing at least 65 percent in such securities. The Investment Company Act of 1940 allows registered open-end investment companies to invest at least 65 percent of their total assets in securities deemed comparable in quality to specified securities. This exemption is subject to the provisions of sections 9 and 38 through 51 for enforcement. The Investment Company Act of 1940 allows registered open-end investment companies to invest in securities comparable in quality. Companies relying on this exemption must file a notification with the Commission. The provisions of sections 9 and 38 through 51 apply to these companies for enforcement purposes. The Investment Company Act of 1940 allows registered open-end investment companies to invest in securities of comparable quality. Companies must file a notification with the Commission to rely on this exemption. The exemption may be utilized until the Commission determines otherwise. The Investment Company Act of 1940 allows registered open-end investment companies to invest in securities of comparable quality. Companies must file a notification with the Commission to rely on this exemption. The exemption provided may be subject to additional terms and conditions determined by the Commission as necessary for the public interest or the protection of investors. SEC. 7 amends the Investment Company Act of 1940 by changing the minimum investment amount to $10,000,000. SEC. 8 defines an eligible portfolio company. Section 2(a)(46)(C) of the Investment Company Act of 1940 is amended to set limits on total assets and capital for qualifying companies. The Commission has the authority to adjust these amounts as needed. The Investment Company Act of 1940 is amended to set limits on total assets and capital for qualifying companies, with the Commission having the authority to adjust these amounts as needed. The shareholders' equity less retained earnings should not exceed $2,000,000, unless adjusted by the Commission to reflect changes in accepted indices or indicators for small businesses. SEC. 9 of the Investment Company Act of 1940 is amended to define a business development company, specifying that it does not need to provide significant managerial assistance to certain types of companies. SEC. 10 addresses the acquisition of assets by business development companies. SEC. 10 of the Investment Company Act of 1940 is amended to allow business development companies to acquire assets from any person, subject to SEC regulations. Section 61(a) of the Investment Company Act of 1940 is amended to change the asset coverage requirements for business development companies. The new requirement is set at 200 percent, but companies can have a coverage of not less than 110 percent under certain conditions. Under subparagraphs (A) and (B) of section 18(a)(2), a business development company may have an asset coverage of not less than 110 percent if it meets specific criteria related to income and expenses before issuing senior securities. A business development company must maintain an asset coverage of at least 110 percent before issuing senior securities, based on specific criteria related to income and expenses. Additionally, it must have a significant portion of its assets invested in specified securities as outlined in the preceding paragraphs. A business development company must meet specific asset coverage requirements before issuing senior securities, with a significant portion of its assets invested in specified securities. It is prohibited from issuing senior securities representing indebtedness without provisions to restrict such actions. It is illegal for a business development company to issue senior securities representing indebtedness without restrictions on dividends, distributions, or stock purchases. A business development company must have an asset coverage of at least 110 percent when declaring dividends, distributions, or purchasing capital stock. Compliance with certain requirements is necessary, except for amounts needed for distribution maintenance. A business development company must maintain an asset coverage of at least 110 percent when declaring dividends or purchasing stock. It is unlawful for the company to issue senior securities without provisions to prevent stock declaration. It is unlawful for a business development company to issue senior securities without provisions to prevent stock declaration of dividends or purchasing stock. The business development company must have an asset coverage of at least 110 percent when declaring dividends or purchasing common stock, and comply with specified requirements. The business development company must maintain an asset coverage of at least 110 percent when declaring dividends or purchasing common stock, and comply with specific requirements to retain its status as a regulated investment company under the Internal Revenue Code of 1986. The business development company must maintain an asset coverage of at least 110 percent when declaring dividends or purchasing common stock to retain its status as a regulated investment company under the Internal Revenue Code of 1986. Amendments include changes to paragraphs regarding securities and indebtedness. The business development company can issue warrants, options, or rights to subscribe to voting securities without accompanying securities, subject to certain conditions. A business development company may issue warrants, options, or rights to subscribe to voting securities without accompanying securities, subject to specific conditions and shareholder/partner authorization. The issuance of warrants, options, or rights by a business development company must be authorized by shareholders or partners and approved by the required majority of directors or general partners.
